message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, signs, and physical examination are consistent with an atrial septal defect with left-to-right shunt causing right ventricular volume overload. This can result in anterior movement of the ventricular septum during systole on echocardiogram. The other options are not consistent with the diagnosis of atrial septal defect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests the diagnosis of atrial septal defect (ASD). The presence of a wide fixed split in the second heart sound, a medium-pitched systolic ejection murmur and a short mid-diastolic rumble over the lower left sternal border suggests the possibility of ASD with the development of pulmonary hypertension. On an echocardiogram, anterior movement of the ventricular septum during systole is the most typical finding seen in ASD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest a diagnosis of an atrial septal defect (ASD) with right ventricular volume overload. The best answer choice is anterior movement of the ventricular septum during systole, which is a characteristic finding in ASD seen on echocardiogram. Decreased right ventricular end-diastolic dimension and goose-neck deformity of left ventricular outflow tract are not typically seen in ASD. Increased left ventricular shortening fraction may be seen in cases of aortic stenosis or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which are not suggested by the patient's history or physical exam.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The wide fixed split in the second heart sound and the medium-pitched systolic ejection murmur suggest an atrial septal defect. Anterior movement of ventricular septum during systole is a classic finding on echocardiogram for atrial septal defect. The other options are not typically associated with atrial septal defects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest the patient has an atrial septal defect (ASD), which causes a left-to-right shunt of blood. The best option is anterior movement of the ventricular septum during systole, which is a hallmark finding on echocardiography in patients with ASD. Decreased right ventricular end-diastolic dimension is seen in pulmonary hypertension. Goose-neck deformity of left ventricular outflow tract is seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Increased left ventricular shortening fraction is not specific to any cardiac pathology.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The wide fixed split in the second heart sound and the systolic ejection murmur suggests that the patient may have an atrial septal defect (ASD). The short mid-diastolic rumble is also audible over the lower left sternal border, which is best heard with the bell of the stethoscope suggests that the ASD is associated with an increased flow across the tricuspid valve, causing an increase in right ventricular volume overload. Anterior movement of the ventricular septum during systole is a characteristic feature seen on echocardiography in patients with ASD. Therefore, this option is the correct answer. Decreased right ventricular end-diastolic dimension is seen in patients with restrictive cardiomyopathy, and goose-neck deformity of left ventricular outflow tract is seen in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Increased left ventricular shortening fraction is seen in patients with dilated cardiomyopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The wide fixed split in the second heart sound and medium-pitched systolic ejection murmur suggest that the patient has an atrial septal defect (ASD). On echocardiogram, the most likely finding would be an anterior movement of the ventricular septum during systole due to increased blood flow from the left atrium to the right atrium through the defect. Decreased right ventricular end-diastolic dimension is not typically seen in ASD. Goose-neck deformity of left ventricular outflow tract is seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Increased left ventricular shortening fraction is seen in conditions with increased left ventricular contractility.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest atrial septal defect (ASD), with a wide fixed split in the second heart sound and a medium-pitched systolic ejection murmur. On echocardiogram, anterior movement of the ventricular septum during systole is characteristic of ASD. Decreased right ventricular end-diastolic dimension and goose-neck deformity of left ventricular outflow tract are not typical findings of ASD. Increased left ventricular shortening fraction may occur in response to increased preload or afterload, but it is not specific to ASD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The wide fixed split in the second heart sound, systolic ejection murmur, and mid-diastolic rumble suggest atrial septal defect and pulmonary hypertension. Option (B), anterior movement of ventricular septum during systole, is a common finding in atrial septal defects. Decreased right ventricular end-diastolic dimension and goose-neck deformity of left ventricular outflow tract are not typical findings in this condition. Increased left ventricular shortening fraction is more likely to be seen in conditions where the left ventricle has to compensate for increased workload or volume overload, neither of which are present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The wide fixed split in the second heart sound and medium-pitched systolic ejection murmur suggest an atrial septal defect (ASD). The anterior movement of ventricular septum during systole is a classic finding on echocardiogram for ASD. The other options are not associated with ASD.
